comments.commentBody: The diagnosis is most likely serotonin syndrome.

I have to say that what I enjoyed even more than the article itself, was the recurring commentary/rejoinders by 'Tara of San Francisco'. The hope of seeing yet another comment headed 'Tara' kept me scrolling from start to finish. Thanks, Tara!

Power isn't the crux of this situation. Physicians who are able to refuse to treat a violent patient, can do so. Nurses tend not to refuse, not because we're worried about our job, (although most nursing laws warn against abandonment of patients), but because aggressive, abusive, and hostile patients are a part of the normal health care system. We are taught how to manage the situation, and it is a team effort, as is so much of nursing. If we refuse the patient, that means our colleague will be assigned to him or her. When I worked on a floor in the hospital, we would usually would switch off so none of us would burn out.

.

Appropriate you cite BMI - ASCAP

Everyone can do their own research on this, Wiki has some good info, but the history of those two 'Music Groups' presents an interesting comparison.

In early days of Radio most everything was 'live' but by late 1930s 'records' started to take over. As this happened, ASCAP wanted $0.10 per song played 'on air' but the Radio Stations only wanted to pay $0.05 (or something to that effect).

So the Stations stopping playing ASCAP songs, which at the time were mostly Crooners and Big Band. They then formed BMI and played Non-ASCAP 'Alternative Music' (for that time) such as Hillbilly (later C&W) and Race (later R&B).

Those program changes allowed many around the USA to hear Songs/Music they'd never heard before, and that (in the opinion of many Music Historians) planted the seeds for what was to become Rock and Roll (that 'magic combo' of C&W and R&B).

Well, if ASCAP had not been so greedy, if they had settled for something less than $0.10 per song ?

No way to know for sure - but might we still be waiting for Elvis ?

.

Now, the 'current status quo', in today's Digital Global Village, will eventually face changes similar to those brought by Radio and Recordings 50 to 100 years ago.

Changes that will, no doubt, have a unique Historical Consequence to match those brought by the Printing Press 500 years ago.

And when it happens, Gutenberg and Elvis should be laughing with delight.

.

"harvard medical school in ethics quandary nytimes com"
the link is to a trainee doctors revolt at Harvard in protest at how Pharma is influencing their studies and preparing them for selling Pharma drugs.
The students say that the way Pharma does business, the corrupt business practices and criminality, the billions of dollars in fines, the bias in research, the false marketing claims, affect the way the public see doctors trained at Harvard. and they want the administration to reduce the influence Pharma have on their training.

Ish - in the 1950s, did you have to pay for TV shows? Were people who watched those shows pirates?

The answer, of course, is no to both. You bought a TV set and turned it on and watched a show...and lots of ads...heck, they were baked into the shows. No one cried piracy back then.
Lesli was my resident when I did my neurology rotation in medical school!  She was a great teacher, and it's a pleasure to see her expertise featured here.
I'm wondering how much the decrease in drug and alcohol use is because you can't surf the net, send text messages, or play video games when you are drunk or high.

For the record industry in Sweden at least the problem is not piracy,
For Universal the major part of income now comes from the legal streaming service Spotify. Which they also happen to partly own and thereby get much more money per stream than everybody else... That being said the real problem is that even as figures look good everybody blames piracy for the decline of physical CD sales. But I don´t think any of them really believe that could we just cripple the internet and throw people in jail the Good Ole Times shall return. They just hope they would.
Natural remedies for back pain are very effective and it doesn't even come with unwanted side effects.
I've been looking for a good Twinkie recipe for years. Care to share?

I have taken a nap every day since Spring 1970 when I contracted Mononucleosis. Almost always with a pre-nap caffeine.
On a Saturday or Sunday, prime nap time is between 2-4 pm. My optimum nap time is 30 minutes, the caffeine begins to bring me back to wakefulness a few minutes before the 30 minutes is up.
I sleep well at night, and the nap makes it seem as if I have 2 good short days, instead of one long day with ragged middle.
When I was in the Navy as a Hospital Corpsman, I would nap on the Marine helicopter on the way to a rescue. I am now 60 years old, and I don't intend to give up this habit.
I have no idea if the naps are involved, but I don't get headaches..ever, I am the only person I know who has never had a headache.

Having grown up in a fantastic suburb (of Toronto) and now living in a fantastic city (NYC) and having lived in all manor of wonderful and dismal places in between, I can say that it is the culture much more than the infrastructure that determines human health outcomes.

Now as an architect and planner I dedicate my work to helping designers, leaders and policy-makers see that culture-change has to come with any infrastructural change if we want to see progress of any kind.

The fact that kids do not walk to school has little to do with street design (I walked 3/4 mile to school when I was 5 years old, and now in the same neighborhood with the identical streets, parents won't let their kids walk a few blocks.) This has everything to do with culture and the fact that we neither know nor trust our neighbor. This in turn has a lot to do with technology allowing and forcing us to go further and further afield for our social and professional circles. Why bother knowing (let alone visiting) my neighbor when I can "talk" to people on the Times website?

Let's put the blame (and solution) where it belongs: with the fact that we have conceded human culture to technocracy. We have abandoned cultural problem-solving as too difficult and too 'personal'. It's easier to buy a new (electric) car, a new (LEED-certified) house, a new (innovative) digital gadget, a new (green) book, or elect a new (socio-technocratic) politician to solve our problems for us, and blame then if they don't.

Hello ROK - Thanks for your feedback. If 29 isn't working for you, then you're a perfect candidate for 26. When my members are having difficulty losing weight at 26, we look really carefully at their food choices - not just the points, but excess sodium, highly processed meats, excessive frozen meals, etc. We also look at activity levels - walking is great, but if you're having trouble losing weight, more vigorous activity might be in order, a little more often. That said, I'm 5'4" and small-boned, and ate everything I was allowed to eat, and was very active as well, and the weight still came off slowly - an average of 0.8 pounds a week when all was said and done. But 2-1/2 years later, I'm maintaining that weight loss and I'm eating extremely well - my entire nutrition program has shifted to naturally sourced, unprocessed foods with lots of fiber and minimal added sugars. That's a miracle for someone who has struggled with weight all of her life. The point I think that got lost in the article is that WW is flexible - if something isn't working for you, you can switch it up. It's not a rote set of rules. It's all based on solid, scientifically grounded nutritional principles and at the end of the day it's a program of suggestions - every member figures out what works for himself/herself and the ones who stick to it, attend meetings for support, and have the patience to figure out what works for them are the members that tend to be the most successful.

The iPhone is superior in every way for people who wants something that just work. People buy the iPhones for the EXPERIENCE and RELIABILITY and couldn't care less about specs.

D'Antoni is second rate coach which is why Lin sat until circumstances forced him into the lineup. When the ball hogs return he'll be sitting again. L

Jeffery, we do not.  It is an unfortunate fact of life, but we do not.  The government is corrupt, and the society/culture funtamentally narcissistic, violent, and dysfunctional.  Help the people in countries where aid organizations actually can do what we are giving them funding to do.  Strange as it may sound, the last I looked AARP was able to give a good idea of which organizations actually provided the highest percentage of donations in direct aid.

I'm crying, too.

How do we get $$ and blankets to that family...8 KIDS DEAD?!?!?

http://atwar.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/02/08/how-to-help-kabuls-refugees/

See the link for organizations.

Is there any rescue organization that can directly get help to these poor people? Please publish NY Times if so. I would gladly give, enough of our tax money has gone into the hands of the war lords. There may be none. The wife of one of my coworkers was murdered in Afghanistan while working for an organization trying to set up a school for women.
I find the comments here about birth control ignorant and inhumane.

Maybe you could travel to Afghanistan and lecture Khan's parents?
And you speak of fun?
Think this through a little harder please.
It starts and ends with compassion and empathy.
Judgment has no place in this scenario.

Before the advent of modern medicine, a woman had to have five or six children to have a statistical chance of two of them surviving to adulthood.  There's a good reason the Bible says go forth and multiply.  Half the population didn't make it past the age of five.  Many women died in childbirth, as did the infants.  The Times ran stats in the late 90s that there were parts of Afghanistan in which almost 75% of the women died in childbirth.  We should be very thankful for the medical care we do have in this country, those of us fortunate enough to have it anyway.

I agree -- it would be great to have some info about effective aid organizations in this area. I've been reading these articles in the Times and I'm flipping out over how sad and preventable it all is.

Just about the most stark, startling story I've read in a long time.  I am consciously aware of people's suffering, but this brought it together in 3D like a cold slap in the face.  I am so thankful for being lucky enough not to have been born into a war torn country, but torn and ill at ease when I know that we can allow this to happen to other human beings.   Wow.
